baseline_groups.claim_summary: Enforcement treatment (conditioning referrer reward on borrower repayment) reduces loan defaults and improves loan performance.
baseline_groups.notes: Enforcement effect is robust: 99% of specs show negative coefficients, 59% significant at 5%. Strongest effects on charged_off (default) outcome. Baseline charged_off coefficient: -0.102 (p=0.016).

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Selection treatment (asking referrers to screen borrowers) improves loan performance through peer screening.
baseline_groups.notes: Selection effect is weak: 94% positive but 0% significant at 5%. Baseline repaid coefficient: 0.039 (p=0.41). Point estimates are consistently positive but never achieve significance.

global_notes: 2x2 factorial RCT of peer referral mechanisms in consumer credit (South Africa). Small sample: only 243 loans with outcome data from 4,454 referrals. 236 total specs, with each outcome x treatment combination tested separately. Enforcement effect is the main robust finding; selection effect is consistently null. Specs come in pairs (enforcement/selection) for each outcome.
